I thought such a Ditty was writ</br>By some Shepherd, inspir'd by Pan:</br>Simplicity, Softness, and Wit,</br>Through each Stanza so prettily ran.
('Mongst the Grottoes, the Lawns, and the Plains,</br>Those Regions of Pleasure and Love;</br>Where Nature condoles with the Swains,</br>And the Nymphs tender Sentiments move.)
But when, undeceiv'd, I knew</br>'Twas a spiritual Shepherd that wrote;</br>Without e'er a Pause I guess'd who,</br>And trac'd you in every Thought.
Divinity sure must indite,</br>And Charity fire our Breast,</br>To compassionate Damon's sad plight;</br>And your Eloquence furnish the rest.
Assemblies dissolve into Joy,</br>And Philomel thinks she's above;</br>When your Thoughts Hallelujahs employ,</br>And a God, or a Heaven of Love.
But when you describe the last Day,</br>And dwell on the Regions of Woe;</br>An impartial Tribunal display,</br>And all the dire Terrors below:
Emotions swell every Breast,</br>And Tears of Repentance their Eyes;</br>Astonished Throngs are possess'd</br>With the Passions of Awe, and Surprize.
When disconsolate Damon, alone,</br>Thus utters in Silence his Sighs;</br>What Heart, that can feel, does not moan,</br>And in Sorrow and Sympathy rise?
Her Breast must be harder than Steel,</br>Not to soften with such a soft Muse:</br>'Twill soon make her Fortitude reel;</br>Sure Nisa can never refuse.
The Swain will soon have his desire;</br>The Courtship will soon have an end:</br>The Lady will Damon admire;</br>And Damon remember his Friend.</br>
